Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider A prostate biopsy is 20 minutes at most, cystoscopy is less than that. I felt like crap for several hours after my biopsies, and I wasn't sedated at all. I would get them both at the same time, save a trip, get your diagnosis a little quicker. Thanks for your response, Southsider. Your point about getting the results back quicker by having them both done at the same time is a good one. And indeed, it does same me a trip back. Cheers!
Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy AND Cystoscopy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Skipper Chuck I've had both,although not on the same day. They're unpleasant but not terribly painful, at least in my case. I agree with Southsider, get them done and out of the way. Good luck, man - keep us posted! Chuck - Thanks for sharing your experience with me and for the good luck wishes. I'll let you know how goes. Max
Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy AND Cystoscopy

Posts.Content: Well I guess the title sort of says it all. In a couple of weeks I am scheduled to have a cystoscopy (for blood in the urine) and a prostate biopsy (family history of PCa, PSA of 11, African-American) on the same day - back to back. I will be sedated with a benzodiazepine and will receive local anesthesia. I'm wondering if this seems like a lot to you to have both of these procedures together), or if anyone has gone through having these back to back like that. I'm not looking forward to it to say the least.

Posts.Content: Hello. One week ago I had my RALP surgery and today had the catheter removed. I received the very good news from my doctor that the cancer was confined to the prostate, and that by removing the prostate I should now be cancer free. My question, however, is about incontinence. Since having the catheter removed this morning, I am now completely incontinent and am leaking like a sieve. I am currently on leave from work until early next month, and am wondering how I would work having to go through 8 or so Depends pads a day. How did you guys deal with being at work while incontinence? Should I extend my leave? (work is offering me 12 weeks of leave if necessary). What was your experience like? What do you think I should do?
Posts.Title: Working With Incontinence

Posts.Content: Hello. One week ago I had my RALP surgery and today had the catheter removed. I received the very good news from my doctor that the cancer was confined to the prostate, and that by removing the prostate I should now be cancer free. My question, however, is about incontinence. Since having the catheter removed this morning, I am now completely incontinent and am leaking like a sieve. I am currently on leave from work until early next month, and am wondering how I would work having to go through 8 or so Depends pads a day. How did you guys deal with being at work while incontinence? Should I extend my leave? (work is offering me 12 weeks of leave if necessary). What was your experience like? What do you think I should do?
Posts.Title: Working With Incontinence

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Unless you have other issues it will improve quickly. I remember looking down as it just ran out. Within a few days I was good with the big pads and one or two nights with diapers and a sit pad in bed. Only ended up using a few diapers. Did you do kegels in preparation? Start them now. It will take a few days for the numbness to clear up and catheter use itself leaves some incontinence because everything stops being used. I don't see a signature so have no info on your age. Typically, the older you are the longer it takes. Surgeon should be able to tell you if he had to take a lot and will have a good idea on how quickly it will come back. 3 months is good. 6 months is average. Getting to a point where pads work happens quickly. I was back to work with the catheter. I have an office job. Thanks, Another. I am 50 years old and have a job where I am mostly standing. My doctor instructed me to wait 6 weeks before beginning kegels (I will begin physical therapy at that time). One other thing - I do not feel the urge to urinate. Did you experience this? Am I still supposed to try and pee, or just let it all leak in the pad until the urge returns?

Posts.Title: Working With Incontinence

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kendadi Hi Max. I had my surgery 2 weeks after receiving my biopsy results ( Gleason 7). I chose laparoscopic instead of robotic because that would have pushed back surgery date another month. My doctor assured me he was proficient in both. With my post surgery Gleason score upgraded to 9 (4+5), and Psa still undetectable at 6 months, I feel confident that I made the right decision. Two weeks! That is great, and that kind of prompt scheduling is what I'm hoping for. Thanks for sharing!
Posts.Title: Time to Schedule Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Hi Maximus. I too wanted my surgery as soon as possible, and since my uro was my surgeon, I was able to have my open RP about 6 weeks after my biopsy. If you have a look at Topic (I) Surgery, #19, #25, #35 and #36 in the Subforum (near the top of the main Forum page), you can read studies on RP timing. One study that looked at adverse findings in the path reports and BCR suggested that 2 months was an acceptable max length for high-risk men: However another study was more generous when examining long-term outcomes: Two studies found RALP can be safely done sooner than the recommended 6-8 weeks. I would choose the best surgeon you can keeping within a reasonable time frame and not let a sense of urgency compromise my choice. Have you had your CTs and bone scan? These need to be scheduled before surgery. If you could create a signature with your salient info, it will both save you typing time and help Forum Brothers be more specific in their replies to your questions. For instructions, see the Sticky Post near the top of the thread list How to List your Stats... Best of luck to you! Djin Hi DjinTonic - Yes, I have had a bone scan and CT, and thankfully both were negative. My surgeon does want me to still have an MRI prior to surgergy, and that has been scheduled for 4 weeks from now. I'm hoping that he will be willing to schedule my surgery even though I haven't had the MRI yet. We'll see. Thanks for the topic recommendations!
Posts.Title: Time to Schedule Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by nmguy Maximus I was a little over 3-1/2 months from diagnosis to surgery. Thankls nmguy. I'm already at 2 months past diagnosis, so 3 1/2 months total would still be great.
Posts.Title: Time to Schedule Surgery

Posts.Content: It looks like I've settled on a hospital and surgeon. I am getting ready to schedule my radical prostatectomy and was curious - how much time did it take for you to schedule your surgery? How far out was your surgeon scheduling? I'm just trying to get a sense for how long I will have to wait. My cancer is aggressive - Gleason score of 8 - and I need to have surgery ASAP. Thanks.

Posts.Content: Well folks, I have officially joined the club. Got a call from my urologist this morning, and I have prostate cancer. He informed me that my cancer (and it feels weird for me to say those words) is "high risk." I will need surgery and likely radiation. The long and short of it is that the right lateral mid is a Gleason 4 + 4, so he informed me that if we don't treat it, it will metastasize. I want to thank you guys for being such a great support as I went through my cystoscopy and transrectal prostate biopsy. The next steps, he informed me, will be to get a bone scan done to make sure it has not spread to my bones, and a CAT scan to make sure it has not spread to my lymph nodes and surrounding tissues. I will let you know when these results come in. Thanks again. Max.
Posts.Title: Pathology Results
